slides.headline: How to Study Effectively (Without Studying More Hours)
The Problem
bullets: Most people study, but don’t learn.
Rereading notes feels productive, but doesn’t stick.
Highlighting builds familiarity, not fluency.
Learning sticks when you retrieve and apply.
slides.note: If studying feels easy, it’s probably not working.

slides.headline: The 3 Rules of Effective Study
bullets: Active recall: force your brain to retrieve.
Spaced repetition: revisit over time, not cramming.
Deliberate practice: target weak spots, not comforts.
slides.note: These three are the difference between ‘I saw it’ and ‘I can do it.’

slides.headline: Active Recall: What to Do
bullets: Blurting: close notes, write all you remember, check gaps.
Practice questions: exam‑style problems, not summaries.
Teach‑back: explain concepts like you tutor someone.
Example: answer 10 questions, mark and fix errors.

slides.headline: Spacing: How to Schedule
bullets: Spacing: short sessions over days beat cramming.
Day 0: learn.
Day 1: recall.
Day 3: recall again.
Day 7: mixed practice.

slides.headline: Interleaving: How to Mix Practice
bullets: Mix topics within a study block.
Don’t grind one topic for hours.
Feels harder; produces stronger learning.
Helps you choose methods under pressure.

slides.headline: The Feedback Loop: Improve Fast
bullets: What did I miss? Why?
What pattern keeps repeating?
What will I do next session?
Rule: mistakes become your study plan.
Spend 70% on weak areas; 30% on review.

slides.headline: A Simple 45‑Minute Study Template
bullets: 0–5: set a specific goal.
5–25: active recall or questions.
25–35: mark and log errors.
35–45: reattempt errors; schedule next review.
slides.note: No fancy motivation needed—just a system.

slides.headline: Make Technique, Not Time, Your Advantage
slides.subheadline: Swap rereading for retrieval, then space it.
